poem:
"Query in the Shadows of Enigma"

Dancing ink tales on crisp parchment,
Constituencies, reborn, yet unborn, whisper.
Would they have turned left, trodden right, or stayed within sight?
Would they have used their fists, released doves, or just done unsaid?
Neither Rallings nor Thrasher, in Plymouth's halls of wisdom, can tell. 
In the teapot of time, only the past leaves stains,
While futures stew, their brew, a hushed riddle yet.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK general election: find your new constituency – and see how it would have voted in 2019 The next general election in the UK will be fought across 650 new constituencies after boundary changes were approved by parliament. While no election has taken place along these boundaries yet, research by psephologists Colin Rallings and Michael Thrasher, academics at the University of Plymouth, has estimated how, based on 2019 results, these new seats would have notionally". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
